data.description: Discover a landscape of contrasting colors, land forms, and textures unlike any other. The park has over 2,000 natural stone arches, hundreds of soaring pinnacles, massive rock fins, and giant balanced rocks. This red-rock wonderland will amaze you with its formations, refresh you with its trails, and inspire you with its sunsets.

entranceFees.description: From April 1 through July 6, 2025, visitors entering the park in a vehicle between 7 am and 4 pm will need to have already purchased a Timed Entry Ticket from Recreation.gov before arriving. One ticket is needed per vehicle. This fee is a Recreation.gov service charge, so it is not waived by any of the interagency passes.
entranceFees.title: Timed Entry Reservation - Park

entrancePasses.description: Valid for one year through the month of purchase. Admits one (1) private, non-commercial vehicle or its pass holder to Arches and Canyonlands national parks, and Natural Bridges and Hovenweep national monuments.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Arches National Park is located in southeast Utah, five miles north of Moab on US 191. From Moab, Utah, drive five miles north on Main Street/US 191. Turn right at the stoplight. From Interstate 70, take exit 182 (Crescent Junction), then drive south 28 miles on US 191. Turn left at the stoplight.

operatingHours.description: Arches National Park is generally open 24 hours a day, year-round. Fees apply. The park is very busy between March and October. To avoid traffic, we recommend entering the park before 8 am or after 3 pm.
operatingHours.name: Park Hours

addresses.line1: 5 miles north of Moab, Utah, on US 191

images.title: An afternoon at Delicate Arch
images.altText: A crowd of people sit and watch the sunset at delicate arch.
images.caption: Exploration awaits at Arches

images.title: Double O Arch
images.altText: a broad, red arch with rock pinnacles in the background
images.caption: Double O Arch is one of many large arches in the Devils Garden area

images.title: Delicate Arch
images.altText: a stone arch
images.caption: Delicate Arch is perhaps the most famous natural arch in the world.

images.title: Milky Way over the Garden of Eden
images.altText: the Milky Way arcs above silhouetted stone pinnacles
images.caption: Arches offers some excellent night sky viewing.

images.title: Park Avenue Trail
images.altText: two hikers descend a broad wash with tall rock walls on either side.
images.caption: The Park Avenue trail is one of many hiking trails at Arches, ranging from easy to strenuous.

data.weatherInfo: Arches is part of the Colorado Plateau, a "high desert" region that experiences wide temperature fluctuations, sometimes over 40 degrees in a single day. The temperate (and most popular) seasons are spring (April-May) and fall (mid-September-October), when daytime highs average 60 to 80 F and lows average 30 to 50 F. Summer temperatures often exceed 100 F, making strenuous exercise difficult. Winters are cold, with highs averaging 30 to 50 F, and lows averaging 0 to 20 F.
data.name: Arches

data.description: Hoodoos (irregular columns of rock) exist on every continent, but here is the largest concentration found anywhere on Earth. Situated along a high plateau at the top of the Grand Staircase, the park's high elevations include numerous life communities, fantastic dark skies, and geological wonders that defy description.

entrancePasses.description: Valid for entry into Bryce Canyon National Park for 12 months from purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: From the North: Take I-15 south to UT-20 (exit 95). Travel east on UT-20 to US-89. Follow US-89 south to UT-12. Travel east on UT-12 to UT-63. Take UT-63 south to Bryce Canyon NP. From the South through Zion National Park: Take I-15 north to UT-9 (exit 16). Follow UT-9 east through Zion National Park to US-89. Travel north on US-89 to UT-12. Go east on UT-12 to UT-63. Take UT-63 south to Bryce Canyon NP. From the East Travel west on UT-12 to UT-63. Take UT-63 south to Bryce Canyon NP.

operatingHours.description: Bryce Canyon National Park is open 365 days a year, 24 hours a day.
operatingHours.name: Park is Open 24-7

images.title: Bryce Amphitheater from Inspiration Point
images.altText: A red rock landscape and plateau forest glows with the morning sun
images.caption: Viewpoints of the iconic Bryce Amphitheater are located along the first 3 miles of the park road and are a popular destination at sunrise.

images.title: Winter sunrise at Sunset Point
images.altText: Snow blankets a red rock landscape of tall rock spires beneath an early morning sky
images.caption: Here at 8,000' (2438 m) winter comes early and stays late. Snow transforms the landscape and requires seasonal closures in some areas and trails.

images.title: Milky Way over the Hoodoos
images.altText: The center of the Milky Way galaxy is seen rising above a horizon of forest and red rock spires
images.caption: Bryce Canyon's clean air and dark night skies are some of its most precious and vulnerable resources. Full moon nights also provide a unique experience of seeing the park after dark.

images.title: Queen's Garden Trail
images.altText: A lone white rock tower stands surrounded by red rock walls and forest along a trail
images.caption: More strenuous trails below the rim provide up-close views of the hoodoo rock spires, while easier walks along the rim give perspective from above.

images.title: Bristlecone Loop trail near Yovimpa Point
images.altText: Red and white rock cliffs lightly dusted with snow with a forest atop them and a long view beyond
images.caption: The park's highest elevations at its southern end and backcountry areas provide views of over 100 miles (161 km) atop high steep cliffs.

data.weatherInfo: Due of its high elevation climate, weather at Bryce Canyon through autumn, winter, and spring can be highly variable. From October to May temperatures fall below freezing nearly every night. The park typically experiences its coldest and snowiest periods from December through February. Spring storms in March and April can still produce heavy snowfall that may impact travel in the region. Summer highs are typically in the 70s-80s F and afternoon thunderstorms are common in July and August.
data.name: Bryce Canyon

data.description: Follow in the footsteps of over 250,000 emigrants who traveled to the gold fields and rich farmlands of California during the 1840s and 1850s: the greatest mass migration in American history. The California National Historic Trail is over 5,000 miles long and covers portions of 10 states. Step into history along more than 1,000 miles of ruts and traces from travelers and their overland wagons.
data.directionsInfo: Those portions of the California National Historic Trail authorized by Congress include nearly 2,000 miles of historic trail that was once the primary "road" taken by farmers, enterprising business managers, gold-seekers, and fortune hunters who chose to make a new life on the California frontier. The route passes through ten states from Missouri to California.

operatingHours.description: The California National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a corridor that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operation and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: California National Historic Trail

images.title: Wagon at Register Rock in City of Rocks National Reserve
images.altText: A white canvas wagon sits in front of a large rock buttress with mountains in the distance.
images.caption: Wagon at Register Rock in City of Rocks National Reserve

images.title: A creek in Carlin Canyon, Nevada on the California Trail
images.altText: A still creek winds through brown rolling hills.
images.caption: A creek in Carlin Canyon, Nevada on the California Trail

images.title: Trail ruts on through Humboldt Wells in Nevada
images.altText: A dirt road passes through sagebrush and a white post with a mountain in the background.
images.caption: Trail ruts on through Humboldt Wells in Nevada

images.title: Devil's Gate, Wyoming
images.altText: A rock buttress with a notch in it surrounded by sagebrush flats.
images.caption: Devil's Gate was an important emigrant landmark in Wyoming.

images.title: View of West Pass on Carson Route
images.altText: Pine trees partly obscure a distant mountain lake with snow-capped mountains.
images.caption: View of West Pass on the Carson Route of the California NHT.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the California National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: weather.gov
data.name: California

multimedia.title: Alcove Spring – Place to visit on the Oregon & California national historic trails
Ash Hollow/Windlass Hill – Places to visit on the Oregon & California national historic trails

data.description: Canyonlands invites you to explore a wilderness of countless canyons and fantastically formed buttes carved by the Colorado River and its tributaries. Rivers divide the park into four districts: Island in the Sky, The Needles, The Maze, and the rivers themselves. These areas share a primitive desert atmosphere, but each offers different opportunities for sightseeing and adventure.

emailAddresses.description: We check this email inbox at least once a week. We will respond to your email as soon as we can.

entranceFees.description: Admits one private, non-commercial vehicle (15 passenger capacity or less) and all its occupants.

data.directionsInfo: Canyonlands National Park is cut into three land districts by the Green and Colorado rivers. Island in the Sky, in the north of the park, is about 40 minutes from Moab, UT via UT 313. The Needles district is in the southeast corner of Canyonlands, about 90 minutes from Moab or an hour from Monticello, UT via UT 211. The Maze district, in the west of the park, is the most remote and challenging; its ranger station is down 46 miles of dirt road from UT 24. All roads in The Maze require high-clearance 4WD.

operatingHours.description: Canyonlands National Park is generally open 24 hours a day, year-round.
operatingHours.name: Open Year-round

addresses.line1: Island in the Sky - 33 miles from Moab on UT 313
addresses.line3: The Maze - 68 miles from Hanksville off UT 24 - unpaved roads
addresses.line2: The Needles - 49 miles from Monticello on UT 211

images.title: Mesa Arch
images.altText: a broad stone arch with rock pinnacles in the distance
images.caption: Mesa Arch, at Island in the Sky, is a great spot for photographers.

images.title: Pothole Point
images.altText: shallow pools with a double rainbow in the background
images.caption: Pothole Point Trail

images.title: The Maze
images.altText: a rugged canyon
images.caption: The Maze is the most remote district of the park. Visiting requires four-wheel drive, self-reliance, and extra time.

images.title: White Rim Road
images.altText: a long gravel road with cyclists on it
images.caption: The White Rim Road at Island in the Sky is a popular road for mountain bikers.

images.title: The Needles in Chesler Park
images.altText: pinnacles of horizontally striped sandstone
images.caption: The Needles, pinnacles of Cedar Mesa Sandstone, are visible in many parts of the Needles District, including this view in Chesler Park.

images.title: Boating on the Colorado River
images.altText: a person rowing a dory on the Colorado River
images.caption: Boating the Colorado and Green rivers is a popular activity at Canyonlands (permit required).

data.weatherInfo: Canyonlands is part of the Colorado Plateau, a "high desert" region that experiences wide temperature fluctuations, sometimes over 40 degrees in a single day. The temperate (and most popular) seasons are spring (April-May) and fall (mid-September-October), when daytime highs average 60 to 80 F and lows average 30 to 50 F. Summer temperatures often exceed 100 F, making strenuous exercise difficult. Winters are cold, with highs averaging 30 to 50 F, and lows averaging 0 to 20 F.
data.name: Canyonlands

data.description: Located in south-central Utah in the heart of red rock country, Capitol Reef National Park is a hidden treasure filled with cliffs, canyons, domes, and bridges in the Waterpocket Fold, a geologic monocline (a wrinkle on the earth) extending almost 100 miles.

data.directionsInfo: From I-70: Take exit 149, then take UT-24 west toward Hanksville; continue for 43.8 miles (70.5 km). Turn right to continue on UT-24 west and continue for 37.3 miles (60 km). From I-15: take exit 188 then US-50 east toward Scipio. Left on UT-50; continuing 0.7 miles (1.1 km). Turn right onto US-50 east; continue for 24.4 miles (39.3 km). Turn right onto UT-260 south and continue 4.2 miles (6.8 km), then right on UT-24 for 71.3 miles. UT-12: North on highway 12 to Torrey, UT. Right onto UT-24.

operatingHours.description: Capitol Reef is a 24 hour park, open all day, every day. The visitor center is open daily, except for some major holidays. Visitor center hours vary, call 435-425-3791 and follow the prompts for current visitor center information.
operatingHours.name: Capitol Reef National Park

images.title: Gifford House and Pendleton Barn
images.altText: Wingate Sandstone cliffs behind historic barn and farmhouse
images.caption: Windgate sandstone towers above historic Fruita farms and homes

images.title: Hickman Bridge
images.altText: A hiker stands beside Hickman Bridge, a natural sandstone bridge
images.caption: Hickman Bridge, a natural sandstone bridge, is a popular hike in the park.

images.title: Strike Valley
images.altText: Exposed layers of rock in the Waterpocket fold
images.caption: The Strike Valley shows colorful layers in the Waterpocket fold.

images.title: Capitol Reef Visitor Center with "The Castle"
images.altText: Cliffs known as "The Castle" tower above the Capitol Reef Visitor Center
images.caption: The Capitol Reef Visitor Center sits below cliffs known as "The Castle".

images.title: Capitol Reef Peach Orchard
images.altText: Fruit tree with peaches in front of red sandstone cliffs
images.caption: The Capitol Reef Orchards, planted in the pioneer era, remain a popular place for visitors today.

data.weatherInfo: Weather is posted daily; check at the park visitor center for weather updates. Do not enter into narrow canyons if there is a threat of rain or if rain has been falling in the area. Rain and snow may also make dirt roads impassable to vehicles.
data.name: Capitol Reef

data.description: Crowning the Grand Staircase, Cedar Breaks sits at over 10,000 feet and looks down into a half-mile deep geologic amphitheater. Come wander among timeless bristlecone pines, stand in lush meadows of wildflowers, ponder crystal-clear night skies and experience the richness of our subalpine forest.

entranceFees.description: All Commercial Vehicles are $10 per person.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: Admits one private, non-commercial vehicle (15 passenger capacity or less) and all its occupants for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entrancePasses.description: Cedar Breaks annual pass provides access to the park for twelve months from the date of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Cedar Breaks National Monument is located east of Cedar City, Utah, just a short drive from Interstate-15. The park is centrally located between Zion and Bryce Canyon National Parks. For detailed driving directions, please visit our Directions & Transportation page by clicking the green button below.

operatingHours.description: Visitor access, services, and activities vary by season. The road through the park, State Route-148, is open to vehicle access between late-May and mid-October. Road access is snow dependent. Visitor services and facilities vary, visit the Operating Hours and Seasons or Current Conditions pages for more information.
operatingHours.name: Park Hours

addresses.line1: Cedar Breaks National Monument: Administrative Office

images.title: Cedar Breaks Amphitheater
images.altText: The ground falls away from the viewer creating brilliant rock formations of pink, red, and orange.
images.caption: Cedar Breaks Amphitheater

images.title: Cedar Breaks Information Center
images.altText: A small log cabin with a stone chimney on one side.
images.caption: This log cabin built in 1937 housing the information center and park store.

images.title: Wildflowers
images.altText: Yellow sunflowers and orange paint-brush wildflowers in a meadow.
images.caption: Cedar Breaks is famous for wildflowers blooming throughout the summer!

images.title: Bristle-cone Pine Tree
images.altText: Ancient Bristle-cone pine with sun shining through the branches.
images.caption: Ancient Bristle-cone pines grow along the rim at Cedar Breaks National Monument.

images.title: Bluebells on the Rim
images.altText: Bluebell flowers growing on the rim of the Cedar Breaks Amphitheater.
images.caption: Bluebell flowers growing on the rim.

data.weatherInfo: Cedar Breaks sits at over 10,000 feet in elevation and is usually 10-20 degrees cooler than surrounding parks. Be prepared for cooler temperatures and unpredictable weather. Snow, sleet, and hail can occur at any time of the year, even in the summer! Summer-time highs are between 60 and 70°F and night-time lows dip to 30-40s°F. Thunderstorms frequently develop in the afternoons. Be aware of lightning and avoid exposed trails and overlooks until storms pass.
data.name: Cedar Breaks

data.description: 150 million years ago, dinosaurs roamed here. Their fossils are still embedded in the rocks. Today, mountains, desert, and rivers flowing in canyons support a variety of life. Petroglyphs reveal the lives and connections of Indigenous people to this land. Homesteaders and outlaws found refuge here. Whether your passion is science, adventure, history, or scenery, Dinosaur offers much to explore.

entranceFees.description:
Non-commercial group fees (per vehicle): 
Vehicle capacity of 15 or less: $25 
Vehicle capacity of 16-25: $15 per person age 16 and older, not to exceed $60. 
Vehicle capacity of 26+: $15 per person age 16 and older, not to exceed $150. 
You may use Annual and Lifetime passes. A pass will cover the pass holder and up to three people traveling with the group.
Pass is valid for reentry for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Non-commercial Groups

entranceFees.description:
National Park Service regulations allow school groups and other bona fide national and international academic institutions to obtain a waiver for park entrance fees, provided that the visit is for educational or scientific purposes, and the resources or facilities the group proposes to use support those purposes.

Fee waivers must be obtained in advance and cannot be issued at the entrance station or visitor center.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Education/Academic Groups

entrancePasses.description: Valid for one year through the month of purchase. Admits one (1) private, non-commercial vehicle or its pass holder to Dinosaur National Monument.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Dinosaur National Monument is located on the Colorado and Utah border with parts of the monument in both states. Dinosaur fossils are only visible in the Utah portion of the monument, not on the Colorado side. The Quarry Visitor Center and Exhibit Hall (where you see the dinosaur fossils) are located approximately 7 miles north of Jensen, Utah. The Canyon Visitor Center is located in Dinosaur, Colorado.

operatingHours.description: The outdoor areas in the monument is open 24 hours per day. Facilities such as visitor centers and the Quarry Exhibit Hall have specific hours of operation. Visit the Operating Hours & Seasons page for more information on facility hours. Some areas of the monument may close in the winter due to snow.
operatingHours.name: Dinosaur National Monument Hours

images.title: Camarasaurus Skull
images.altText: the fossilized skull of camarasaurus dinosaur
images.caption: Over 1500 fossilized bones of various dinosaurs are still embedded in the cliff face including a skull and several neck vertebrae of a camarasaurus

images.title: Jones Hole Canyon
images.altText: A large sandstone canyon with golden grasses and green trees growing inside.
images.caption: The Jones Hole Trail offers remote solitude in the wilderness of the monument.

images.title: Steamboat Rock and the Green River in Echo Park
images.altText: the rocky pinnacle of Steamboat Rock rises over the Green River
images.caption: Steamboat Rock rises above the Green River in Echo Park

images.title: McKee Springs Petroglyphs
images.altText: Ancestral Native American rock art at McKee Springs
images.caption: The ancestral indigenous peoples left petroglyphs on many of the rock cliffs within Dinosaur National Monument including those at McKee Springs

images.title: Jones Hole Creek
images.altText: A small waterfall in a fast flowing creek, moving through a green forest.
images.caption: Jones Hole Creek flows year round, providing nourishment for vibrant, green forests.

images.title: Camarasaurus Hump Specimen
images.altText: Large bones resembling legs, ribs and the vertebrae of a neck embed grayish brown rock.
images.caption: Fossils from a camarasaurus dinosaur display the well articulated specimens still found in the rock in the Quarry Exhibit Hall.

images.title: Mitten Park from Harpers Corner
images.altText: view of a river flowing through a deep canyon
images.caption: Hikers arriving at the end of the Harpers Corner Trail are rewarded with a view of the Mitten Park Fault, Green River and the Yampa River Canyons

images.title: Night Sky over Tent
images.altText: the star filled sky above a tent
images.caption: Dinosaur's dark skies provides dramatic views of the Milky Way Galaxy

images.title: Rocky Mountain Bighorns
images.altText: A bighorn sheep lamb stands in front of a bighorn ewe.
images.caption: Visitors to Dinosaur may also see its diversity of wildlife including Rocky Mountain bighorn sheep.

images.title: Floating Rapids
images.altText: A green rubber raft floats over a rapid on a brown colored river in front of multi-colored mountains
images.caption: Rapids like those in Split Mountain Canyon challenge and thrill rafters on the Green River.

data.weatherInfo: Dinosaur's climate is semiarid with temperatures averaging between 0°F to 30°F in January and 50°F to 100°F in July. Extreme winter low temperatures may reach -40°F and summer highs can top 110°F. Elevations within the park vary between 4,700 and 9,000 feet. Winter snow may be heavy at higher elevations while only light to moderate snow is found at lower elevations. Summer thunderstorms may cause heavy downpours and localized flooding, but fail to dampen parched soils less than a mile away.
data.name: Dinosaur

data.description: Encompassing over 1.25 million acres, Glen Canyon National Recreation Area offers unparalleled opportunities for water-based & backcountry recreation. The recreation area stretches for hundreds of miles from Lees Ferry in Arizona to the Orange Cliffs of southern Utah, encompassing scenic vistas, geologic wonders, and a vast panorama of human history.

emailAddresses.description:
Glen Canyon Information.
This inbox is checked weekly.

entranceFees.description: Admits one single, private, non-commercial vehicle and all its passengers.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Admits one single, private, non-commercial motorcycle and its riders.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual when entering on foot or bicycle. Individuals 15 years of age and younger are admitted free.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: Fees are assessed based on the passenger capacity of the vehicle. Pass is only valid for the same group to which it was issued.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van

entranceFees.description: Fees are assessed based on the passenger capacity of the vehicle. Pass is only valid for the same group to which it was issued.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus

entranceFees.description: Fees are assessed based on the passenger capacity of the vehicle. Pass is only valid for the same group to which it was issued.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach

entranceFees.description: Academic fee waivers must be submitted and returned before you visit Glen Canyon National Recreation Area.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Education/Academic Groups

entrancePasses.description: Annual pass is a card signed for and held by the owner. Allows unlimited entry for cardholder and everyone in that person's private vehicle to Glen Canyon National Recreation Area for 12 months from date of purchase. Does not cover vessel expanded amenity fee.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: There are multiple districts in Glen Canyon very far away from each other. Avoid a two hundred mile detour and make sure you know which district you are going to before you begin travelling here.

operatingHours.description: Glen Canyon National Recreation Area is open 24 hours per day, year-round. If there is not a person staffing the entrance station, you may pay your entrance fee at the automated fee machine. Launch ramps are open all day, unless closed due to low water.
operatingHours.name: Glen Canyon Open Hours

operatingHours.description: Glen Canyon National Recreation Area and Rainbow Bridge National Monument Headquarters, located in Page, Arizona. This building is only partially open to the public but sells passes year-round. Park Headquarters is not a visitor center. Please drive five miles north to Carl Hayden Visitor Center for information needs. Open weekdays 7am-4pm, closed weekends and Federal Holidays. Call 928-608-6200 for more information.
operatingHours.name: Park Headquarters

images.title: Enjoy Lake Powell
images.altText: Woman raises her arms while standing in front of a sandstone butte
images.caption: Spending time on Lake Powell near Tower Butte can make anyone excited.

images.title: Horseshoe Bend
images.altText: Green river winds through high cliffs.
images.caption: The Colorado River makes a 270 degree turn at Horseshoe Bend. Watch your step at the 1000 foot drop!

images.title: Glen Canyon Dam
images.altText: A concrete dam plugs high canyon walls. Buildings and wires on the sides.
images.caption: Glen Canyon Dam is the country's second largest gravity arch dam. Take a tour from the Carl Hayden Visitor Center.

images.title: So Many Ways to Find Your Park
images.altText: Three kayaks on the lake.
images.caption: If motorized recreation isn't your thing, take a kayak and paddle through the high side canyons of Lake Powell.

images.title: Lonely Dell Ranch at Lees Ferry Historic District
images.altText: Log cabin and fences with a wooden wagon.
images.caption: Glen Canyon isn't just houseboats and wakeboards. Come down to Lees Ferry Historic District to relive pioneer times when crossing the river was a major undertaking.

data.weatherInfo: The weather in Glen Canyon National Recreation Area is usually typical for the high deserts. Summers are extremely hot with little, if any, shade. Winters are moderately cold with night time lows often below freezing. Spring weather is highly variable and unpredictable with extended periods of winds. Fall weather is usually nice and mild, a great time to beat the heat (and the crowds!).
data.name: Glen Canyon

data.description: One of the greatest technological achievements of the 19th century is the completion of the first transcontinental railroad across the United States. Visitors to the park can see the location of the Last Spike Site, 1869 railroad construction features, walk or drive on the original railroad grade, and get an up close view of Victorian era replica locomotives.

entranceFees.description:
The per vehicle fee covers all occupants in a single private vehicle. The fee will allow visitors access to all resources open to the public, including auto tours, walking trails, films, exhibit areas, ranger guided programs, and other seasonal activities. 

If visitors have any of the America the Beautiful Inter-agency passes, these will cover the pass holder and anyone that is in their personal vehicle.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description:
The motorcycle fee admits the driver and one passenger. The fee will allow visitors access to all resources open to the public, including auto tours, walking trails, films, exhibit area, ranger guided programs, other seasonal activities. 
If visitors have any of the America the Beautiful Inter-agency passes, these will cover the pass holder and the passenger of the motorcycle.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual with no car. This pass is typically used for bicyclists, and pedestrians. Youth 15 and under are admitted free. The fee will allow visitor access to all resources open to the public, including auto tours, walking trails, films, exhibit area, ranger guided programs, other seasonal activities. If visitors have any of the America the Beautiful Inter-agency passes, these will cover the pass holder.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description:
Golden Spike National Historical Park Annual Pass

This annual pass covers entrance fees at Golden Spike National Historical Park for the pass holder and occupants within a single non-commercial vehicle or the pass holder and one passenger on a motorcycle.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Golden Spike National Historical Park is 32 miles west of Brigham City, Utah. NB travelers on I-15: use exit 365 and drive west on Utah 13 and 83 through Corinne (follow brown directional signs) to Golden Spike Drive. Turn left and follow signs to the visitor center (8 miles). SB travelers on I-84: use Howell exit 26 and drive south on Utah 83 (follow brown directional signs) to Golden Spike Drive. Turn right and follow signs to the visitor center (8 miles). Lat/Long 41.617410,-112.550986

operatingHours.description:
All park landscapes and outdoor features are open seven days a week, sunrise to sunset, year-round. This includes the Big Fill Trail, Historic Last Spike Site, East Auto Tour, picnic areas, outdoor exhibits, and restrooms. 
NOTE: Seasonal access to some areas may be limited during the winter months due to weather events and other unforeseen circumstances. See Visitor Center and Park Alerts for seasonal schedules and closures.
operatingHours.name: Park Landscapes and Outdoor Features

images.title: Replica Locomotives Jupiter and #119 at the Last Spike Site
images.altText: Two replica victorian age steam locomotives face each other on the original railroad grade
images.caption: Connect with the history by viewing the site's replica steam locomotives in action

images.title: Golden Spike National Historical Park Visitor Center
images.altText: The Golden Spike National Historical Park's Visitor Center colorful stone entrance
images.caption: Golden Spike's Visitor Center is the best the best place to start your exploration of this unique piece of American History.

images.title: Golden Spike Park Entrance Sign
images.altText: Winter View of Golden Spike Entrance Sign
images.caption: Winter View of Golden Spike Entrance Sign

images.title: The Big Fill
images.altText: The Big Fill is a 400 foot long 80 foot high mound of packed earth that bridged a ravine
images.caption: Visitors can explore fifteen miles of the historic grade that was prepared for track by the two railroad companies

images.credit: Cantor Arts Center of Stanford University
images.title: The Golden Spike
images.altText: The Golden Spike
images.caption: Photo of actual Golden Spike courtesy of Cantor Arts Center at Stanford University

images.title: Locomotives 119 and Jupiter nose to nose at the last spike site.
images.altText: Two locomotives the 119 and Jupiter facing each other on a track.
images.caption: Each day the locomotives are moved to the last spike site to recreate the marriage of the rails.

images.title: Winter View on the Big Fill Trail
images.altText: Winter View on the Big Fill Trail
images.caption: Sunner winter day on the Big Fill Loop Trail.

images.title: Recreation of May 10th Champagne Photo
images.altText: Recreation of May 10th Champagne Photo
images.caption: Recreation of famous Champagne photo during annual May 10th Commemoration.

data.weatherInfo: Golden Spike National Historical Park is located in a high desert environment in the Promontory Mountains near the north end of the Great Salt Lake. The temperatures can reach over 100 degrees in the summer and dip into single digits in the winter, with much of the park blanketed in snow. Visitors are recommended to check forecasts before coming to our site and come prepared for changing weather conditions.
data.name: Golden Spike

data.description: Hovenweep preserves six prehistoric sites built between A.D. 1200 and 1300 which may have served as ceremonial centers. Explore a variety of structures, including multistory towers perched on canyon rims and balanced on boulders. The construction and attention to detail will leave you marveling at the skill and motivation of the builders.

entranceFees.description: Entry fee is valid for 7 days and grants entry for driver and passengers in one private vehicle. Does not cover camping costs.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Entry fee admits one private, non-commercial motorcycle and its rider(s). Each motorcycle must purchase separate entry fee. Entry fee is valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual with no car. This fee type is typically used for bicyclists and pedestrians. Youth 15 and under are admitted free. Entry fee is valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: Valid for one year through the month of purchase. Admits one (1) private, non-commercial vehicle or its pass holder to Arches and Canyonlands national parks, and Natural Bridges and Hovenweep national monuments.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Do not use GPS to find your way. There are numerous paved and dirt roads intersecting each other in this remote corner of Utah. The Hovenweep Visitor Center is located 40-45 miles from Cortez, Colorado, and Blanding and Bluff, Utah. Follow driving directions on our webpage.

operatingHours.description: Hovenweep National Monument is typically open year-round. Park trails are open only sunrise to sunset.
operatingHours.name: All Park Hours

addresses.line1: Along the border between southeast Utah and southwest Colorado
addresses.line2: Just north and west of Cortez, CO

images.title: Milky Way at Square Tower Group
images.altText: a stone structure at night with the Milky Way arcing overhead
images.caption: Hovenweep National Monument was designated an International Dark Sky Park in 2014.

images.title: Claretcup Cactus
images.altText: a bright red cactus flower
images.caption: Claretcup Cactus is a common plant at Hovenweep National Monument

images.title: Stronghold House
images.altText: a stone structure resting on a cliff edge
images.caption: Stronghole House is one of several structures at the Square Tower Group

images.title: Cajon Unit
images.altText: a stone structure with blue sky and clouds overhead
images.caption: The Cajon Unit is one of several outlying units at Hovenweep National Monument.

images.title: Collared Lizard
images.altText: a green lizard with yellow head, yellow spots and black collar
images.caption: Collard lizards are one of many species that call Hovenweep home.

images.title: Holly Group
images.altText: remains of a stone structure with wood beams on the edge of a canyon
images.caption: The Holly Group is one of Hovenweep's outlying sites, but worth the drive or hike.

data.weatherInfo: Hovenweep is part of the Colorado Plateau, a "high desert" region that experiences wide temperature fluctuations, sometimes over 40 degrees in a single day. The temperate (and most popular) seasons are spring (April-May) and fall (mid-September-October), when daytime highs average 60 to 80 F and lows average 30 to 50 F. Summer temperatures often exceed 100 F, making strenuous exercise difficult. Winters are cold, with highs averaging 30 to 50 F, and lows averaging 0 to 20 F.
data.name: Hovenweep

data.description: Explore the Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail across five states to see the 1,300-mile route traveled by Mormons who fled Nauvoo, Illinois, to the Great Salt Lake Valley in 1846-1847.
data.directionsInfo: The Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail crosses five states following the route the Pioneer Company of 1846-1847 established from Nauvoo, Illinois, to Salt Lake City, Utah, covering about 1,300 miles.

operatingHours.description: The Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a corridor that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operation and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail

images.title: Echo Canyon, Utah
images.altText: Red cliffs line a highway as seen from a high point with grass in the foreground.
images.caption: Echo Canyon on the way from Wyoming to Salt Lake City, Utah is both beautiful and historic.

images.title: Brigham Young grave, Utah
images.altText: A bronze plaque with description on a metal fence surrounding Brigham Young's grave.
images.caption: Brigham Young's grave lies in the heart of downtown Salt Lake City, Utah

images.title: Monument Rock, Utah.
images.altText: Red rock monolith in a rocky canyon
images.caption: Monument Rock in Echo Canyon, Utah.

images.title: Joseph & Emma Smith House, Nauvoo, Illinois
images.altText: A large, white, two-story historic wood home with a red roof and white picket fence.
images.caption: Joseph & Emma Smith  House in Nauvoo, Illinois.

images.title: Mormon Pioneer Trail in Utah
images.altText: A hiking trail with a trail sign.
images.caption: There are places you can hike on the historic trail!

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: weather.gov
data.name: Mormon Pioneer

multimedia.title: Carthage Jail - Place to visit on the Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail

data.description: Three majestic natural bridges invite you to ponder the power of water in a landscape usually defined by its absence. View them from an overlook, or hit the trails and experience their grandeur from below. Declared a National Monument in 1908, the bridges are named "Kachina," "Owachomo" and "Sipapu" in honor of the Ancestral Puebloans who once made this place their home.

data.directionsInfo: The entrance to Natural Bridges is at the end of UT 275, which is roughly 35 miles west of Blanding, Utah, on UT 95. Driving time from Blanding is roughly 45 minutes.

operatingHours.description: Natural Bridges National Monument is generally open 24 hours a day, year-round.

data.weatherInfo: Natural Bridges is part of the Colorado Plateau, a "high desert" region that experiences wide temperature fluctuations, sometimes over 40 degrees in a single day. The temperate (and most popular) seasons are spring (April-May) and fall (mid-September-October), when daytime highs average 60 to 80 F and lows average 30 to 50 F. Summer temperatures often exceed 100 F, making strenuous exercise difficult. Winters are cold, with highs averaging 30 to 50 F, and lows averaging 0 to 20 F.
data.name: Natural Bridges

data.description: Follow the routes of mule pack trains across the Southwest on the Old Spanish National Historic Trail between Santa Fe, New Mexico, and Los Angeles, California. New Mexican traders moved locally produced merchandise across what are now six states to exchange for mules and horses.
data.directionsInfo: You can visit many sites of the Old Spanish National Historic Trail over the 2,700-mile historic route that crosses 6 states.

operatingHours.description: There are many places of history and commemoration on the Old Spanish National Historic Trail to visit. Museums, interpretive centers, and historic sites provide information and interpretation. Please contact each site before you go to obtain current information on closures, changes in hours, and fees.
operatingHours.name: Old Spanish National Historic Trail

images.title: Santa Rosa de Lima de Abiquiú, Abiquiú, New Mexico
images.altText: crumbling adobe structure with blue sky
images.caption: Santa Rosa de Lima de Abiquiú provided a way station for travelers along the Old Spanish Trail in the 1800s. It is privately owned by the Archdiocese of Santa Fe.

images.title: Rio Chama River, Abiquiú, New Mexico
images.altText: hikers walk beside a river with cottonwoods alongside the river
images.caption: This section of the Rio Chama River, tributary of the Rio Grande, is located about six miles north of Abiquiú, New Mexico and flows through the Carson National Forest.

images.title: Sierra Blanca, San Luis Valley, Colorado
images.altText: desert scrub in foreground, spiky mountains in background, clouds
images.caption: Sierra Blanca is a prominent mountain in the Sangre de Cristo Range along San Luis Valley on Highway 17. Locating landmarks were essential to traveling the Old Spanish Trail.

images.title: San Rafael Swell, Utah
images.altText: desert scenery, dead tree, blue sky with puffy coulds
images.caption: The San Rafael Swell is a huge craggy geologic feature (an anticline), about 75 miles by 40 miles, located in south-central Utah approximately 30 miles west of Green River.

images.title: Virgin River Canyon, Arizona
images.altText: a river carves through the landscape, greenery in the foreground, mountains and redrock backdrop
images.caption: This section of the Virgin River Canyon Recreation Area is off Interstate 15 about 20 miles southwest of St. George, Utah and about 20 miles northeast of Mesquite, Nevada

images.title: Old Spanish Trail segment, Nevada
images.altText: rocky trail through desert with yucca, mountain in the background
images.caption: This trail segment is 5.25 miles, and is part of the Old Spanish Trail/Mormon Road Historic District, outside Blue Diamond, Clark County, Nevada.

images.title: Mojave Road, California
images.altText: trail through desert scrub with Joshua trees, mountains in the distance, puffy clouds
images.caption: Old Spanish Trail travelers used this section of the historic Mojave Road is within Mojave National Preserve.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of Old Spanish National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: weather.gov

data.description: It is hard to believe that young men once rode horses to carry mail from Missouri to California in the unprecedented time of only 10 days. This relay system along the Pony Express National Historic Trail in eight states was the most direct and practical means of east-west communications before the telegraph.
data.directionsInfo: You can visit many sites of the Pony Express National Historic Trail over the 1,800-mile historic route that crosses 8 states.

operatingHours.description: The Pony Express National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a route that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operations and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: Pony Express National Historic Trail

images.caption: A National Pony Express Association rider poses at Simpson Springs in Utah.

images.caption: Devil's Gate was an important landmark on the trail in Wyoming.

images.title: Schelbourne Station, Nevada

images.caption: A Pony Express rider silhouette can be found at the Schelbourne Station site in Nevada.

images.title: Fort Laramie NHS monument, Wyoming

images.caption: A monument and plaque about the Pony Express can be found at Fort Laramie in Wyoming.

images.title: Stables at St. Joseph
images.altText: A large brick historic stable.
images.caption: Visit the historic stables in St. Joseph, Missouri.

data.description: Rainbow Bridge is one of the world's largest known natural bridges. The span has undoubtedly inspired people throughout time--from the neighboring Native American tribes who consider Rainbow Bridge sacred, to the thousands of visitors from around the world who visit it each year. Please visit Rainbow Bridge in a spirit that honors and respects the cultures to whom it is sacred.

emailAddresses.description: General park Information for Glen Canyon National Recreation Area and Rainbow Bridge National Monument. This box is checked weekly.

data.directionsInfo: Rainbow Bridge National Monument is located between Glen Canyon National Recreation Area and the Navajo Nation. *There are no roads to or near the monument.* Rainbow Bridge can be reached by boat on Lake Powell or by hiking one of two trails around Navajo Mountain on the Navajo Nation, by permit only. Boat tours are available. The entrance to Forbidding Canyon is located at buoy 49 on Lake Powell. Boaters should be familiar with the Aids to Navigation (buoy) system and use a navigational map.

operatingHours.description: Rainbow Bridge National Monument is open every day of the year, from sunrise to sunset. On rare occasions, the park may be closed for visitor safety while significant trail and/or dock repairs are taking place. Contact the park for up-to-date information on any closures in effect. Overnight camping or docking your boat is prohibited.
operatingHours.name: Rainbow Bridge National Monument

addresses.line1: c/o Glen Canyon National Recreation Area
c/o Glen Canyon National Recreation Area

images.title: Rainbow Bridge
images.altText: A large sandstone arch - a natural bridge.
images.caption: Stand here and take in the majesty of Rainbow Bridge - the largest natural bridge in the National Park Service.

images.title: Aerial View of Rainbow Bridge
images.altText: A view of Rainbow Bridge from the air.
images.caption: Seen from the air, Rainbow Bridge is a graceful curve over the dry stream bed.

images.title: A Crowd Views Rainbow Bridge From Its Shadow
images.altText: A large crowd faces away from the camera at the scenery.
images.caption: In the desert heat after the rough walk up to Rainbow Bridge from the docks, you take shade where you can get it.

images.title: Rainbow Bridge Docks
images.altText: Boats and personal watercraft sidle up to docks.
images.caption: The only way to access Rainbow Bridge is by a two-day hike across the Navajo Nation, or a fifty-mile boat trip up Lake Powell.

images.title: Jim Mike Returns to Rainbow Bridge
images.altText: An elderly Native American man sits in a lawn chair under Rainbow Bridge
images.caption: In 1974, Ute Mountain Ute Jim Mike, one of the  guides who led the original expedition to Rainbow Bridge, returned to see how he had led the way for many more visitors.

images.title: Park Ranger at Second Observation Area
images.altText: Park Ranger standing in front of perfectly curved sandstone arch
images.caption: During the summer season, Park Rangers will be at the observation areas to answer your questions.

data.weatherInfo: Summers are extremely hot with little, if any, shade. Winters are moderately cold with night time lows often below freezing. Spring weather is highly variable with extended periods of strong winds. Fall is generally mild. Temperatures range from 110°F (43°C) in June & July to 20°F (-7°C) in December & January. Although precipitation is generally less than 6 inches (15cm) annually, both heavy rains and flash flooding can occur, particularly during the summer monsoon season.
data.name: Rainbow Bridge

data.description: The visitor center, caves, and cave tours are now open for the 2025 season. Hike your way past stunning vistas to explore a hidden underground world. Taste the thrill of caving as you twist and bend to enter beautifully decorated rooms. Learn the science behind formations and hear stories of cave exploration and preservation. Experience and discover as you go – geologic mysteries await

entranceFees.description:
Open seasonally depending on weather. Caves cannot be accessed without a ticket. Tickets are between $2.00 and $12.00 depending on age and are 50% off for the passholder only with a Senior or Access Pass.
This tour spends 55 minutes inside of the cave system with a ranger walking along a 1/3 mile trail. There are multiple stairs and places you must bend and twist. Visitors on this tour will see Hansen Cave, Middle Cave, and Timpanogos Cave.
entranceFees.title: Timed Entry Reservation - Location

entranceFees.description:
Open seasonally depending on weather. Caves cannot be accessed without a ticket. 
Spend an hour inside the Timpanogos Cave System with a ranger on a lantern guided tour. Discover what early explorers experienced as they traveled through the dark passages of the cave. Hear stories of early exploration and marvel at the cave’s geology by the glow of your lantern and experience the caves in a way that hasn't been done in decades.

This tour is limited to those 7 years of age and older.
entranceFees.title: Timed Entry Reservation - Location

entranceFees.description: Open seasonally depending on weather. Caves cannot be accessed without a ticket. With a helmet and headlamp you are ready to experience Hansen Cave in its natural state. With a ranger, you'll scramble and sometimes even crawl on the trail leading to Hansen Cave Lake, along the same route Martin Hansen conducted tours in the late 1800s. The tour is considered strenuous. Must be 14 years of age or older to participate.
entranceFees.title: Timed Entry Reservation - Location

data.directionsInfo: From I-15: Take Exit 284 (Alpine-Highland exit), turn east on State Highway 92 and proceed ten miles (16km) to the monument. UT 40 or U.S. 189: Travel UT 189 through Provo Canyon, west on Orem 800 North (UT 52). After 2.4 miles turn right on State Street UT- 89. After 3.8 miles, turn onto Pleasant Grove 100 East (UT 146). Stay on this road for almost five miles, as it turns in Canyon Road and takes you to the mouth of American Fork Canyon. Turn right up American Fork Canyon to visitor center.

operatingHours.description: The Visitor Center is currently open for the season.
operatingHours.name: Visitor Center

operatingHours.description: Cave tours are available generally late-May through early October.
operatingHours.name: Cave Tours

operatingHours.description:
Picnic areas and Canyon Nature Trail are open year round (weather permitting). 

For up to date information, visit https://www.nps.gov/tica.
operatingHours.name: Picnic Areas

operatingHours.description:
Please Note: Visitors interested in cave tours are not required to stop at this building. Weekend closures of this facility do not affect cave tour operations.

This administrative building contains the PIV/CAC credentialing station and park administrative offices. During the winter season, we recommend calling in advance to ensure staff availability. The building is closed on all federal holidays.
operatingHours.name: Administrative Building

images.altText: Twisty helictites growing off a stalactite
images.caption: Timpanogos Cave is filled with twisting helictites and other beautiful formations

images.title: Timpanogos Cave's "Chimes Chamber"

images.caption: Timpanogos Cave's beautiful Chimes Chamber is filled with delicate cave formations

images.title: Hansen Cave-Introduction to Caving Tour

images.caption: Cavers on the Introduction to Caving Tour admire magnificent formations.

images.title: View from the Timpanogos Cave Trail
images.altText: Utah Valley beyond the steep cliffs and fir trees of American Fork Canyon
images.caption: The scenic view from the trail to the caves is one people often remember.

images.title: Along the Trail to the Caves
images.altText: White-orange quartzite surrounded by greenery stands against a blue sky
images.caption: The trail to the cave leads the hiker past layer after layer of geologic time

data.weatherInfo: Although inside the caves its always 43-48 F, temperatures on the cave trail can range from the 30s up to above 100 degrees F, depending on time of year. Carrying drinking water is a necessity, especially in summer. In the mountains, weather sometimes presents interesting challenges. The cave and cave trail do not close due to rain, unless that rain is heavy enough to bring rockfall. They will close due to high winds/rockfall, or in lightning storms. Call the visitor center if you have specific concerns.
data.name: Timpanogos Cave

data.description: Follow the paths where people have walked for thousands of years. Gaze up at massive sandstone cliffs of cream, pink, and red that soar into a brilliant blue sky. Experience the tall, stretching walls of a narrow slot canyon. Zion’s unique array of plants and animals will enchant you as you absorb the rich history of the past and enjoy the excitement of present-day adventures.

emailAddresses.description: If you cannot find what you need on our website, please write to ask for more information.

entranceFees.description: Admits private, non-commercial vehicle (15 passenger capacity or less) and all occupants to Zion National Park. Valid for 1-7 days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Admits one, non-commercial motorcycle to Zion National Park. Valid for 1-7 days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual with no car to Zion National Park. Typically used for bicyclists, hikers and pedestrians. Youth 15 and under are admitted free. Valid for 1-7 days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Snowmobile

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual with no car to Zion National Park. Typically used for bicyclists, hikers and pedestrians. Youth 15 and under are admitted free. Valid for 1-7 days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: $20 per person. Non-commercial vehicles with a capacity of 16 or greater. Fees will not exceed the commercial fee for the same-sized vehicle. Youth 15 and under are free. Individuals or families with any valid Annual or Lifetime pass may use their pass for entry at the per person rate. Pass and photo ID must be present upon entry.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Non-commercial Groups

entranceFees.description: A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. The entry fees of commercial tours are based upon the total capacity of vehicles that can carry seven or more passengers regardless of the actual number of passengers.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van

entranceFees.description: A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. The entry fees of commercial tours are based upon the total capacity of vehicles that can carry seven or more passengers regardless of the actual number of passengers.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus

entranceFees.description: A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. The entry fees of commercial tours are based upon the total capacity of vehicles that can carry seven or more passengers regardless of the actual number of passengers.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach

entranceFees.description:
A commercial tour is defined as one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. Vehicles with commercial tours of 1-6 people (not including guide) pay $35 per vehicle + $20 per person with a total fee not to exceed $70.

Passengers can use valid weekly, annual, lifetime, or appreciation passes.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: The Zion Annual Pass is valid only at Zion and may be purchased in person. This pass is valid for 12 months from purchase month. This pass admits the pass holder and passengers in a non-commercial vehicle. You can buy this entrance pass at all entrance stations.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Zion National Park's main, south entrance and administrative offices are located near Springdale, Utah You may drive yourself on all open park roads except the Zion Canyon Scenic Drive. During most of the year, the Scenic Drive is accessed by shuttle bus only. Shuttles are free to ride. Board one in Springdale or at the Zion Canyon Visitor Center.

operatingHours.description: Zion National Park is open every day of the year.
operatingHours.name: Zion National Park

images.title: The Watchman
images.altText: A triangular sandstone mountain overlooks green and yellow foliage. A cloudy blue sky is overhead.
images.caption: The Watchman in Zion Canyon

images.title: The Towers of the Virgin
images.altText: The sun sets behind large red and white towers of sandstone.
images.caption: The Towers of the Virgin in Zion Canyon

images.title: Zion Canyon Visitor Center
images.altText: A sandstone and glass building surrounded by tall trees with a mountain behind it.
images.caption: The Zion Canyon Visitor Center is a great place to stop to learn about the park!

images.title: The Narrows
images.altText: Tall, red, sandstone walls enclose a narrow river.
images.caption: The Narrows can be accessed at the end of Riverside Walk, just follow the river.

images.title: Kolob Arch
images.altText: A red sandstone arch under a clear blue sky.
images.caption: Deep in Zion's Wilderness site Kolob Arch, one of the largest free-standing arches in the world.

data.weatherInfo: Zion is known for a wide range of weather conditions. Temperatures vary with changes in elevation and day/night temperatures may differ by over 30°F. In summer, temperatures in Zion National Park often exceed 100°F/38°C. Zion experiences monsoons from mid-July into September that result in an increased risk of flash floods. Always be aware of the threat of storms and lightning and be prepared for a wide range of weather conditions. Winters are generally mild.
data.name: Zion
